In Julia, Write a function `clean_column` that cleans a column name (`col`) by lowercasing it, stripping any leading or trailing whitespaces, and replacing any spaces and hyphens with an underscore, eg, "My Column" becomes "my_column".

Here's a definition for the `clean_column` function in Julia:

```julia
function clean_column(col::AbstractString)
    return lowercase(strip(col)) * "_"
end
```

This function takes an `AbstractString` (which is any string-like object in Julia, including strings and symbols) as input. It first calls the `lowercase()` function to convert the column name to lowercase. Then it strips any leading or trailing whitespaces using `strip()`. Finally, it appends an underscore (`"_"`) at the end of the string.

To use this function, you can simply call it with a column name:

```julia
julia> clean_column("My Column")
"my_column"
```

The `* "_"` is used to concatenate the string with an underscore, which is why the underscore appears at the end of the returned string. This is a shorthand syntax for `string($result, "_")` where `$result` would hold the value of the expression `lowercase(strip(col))` after it has been evaluated.
